name: Intro
_source: speak;Eirika;Don't forget to buy the milk!
speak;Charles;I was the one who reminded you!
speak;Eirika;Course you will or course you won't?
# Charles exits the house and meets a guy
speak;VillagerMaddy2;Remember the princess who lived around here...
speak;Benson;Come on Malachy!{w}{clear}Put your back into it!;;125;;;;;;1
speak;Farmhand;Back at the village,{w} there were several scattered along the ground.
speak;Benson;Ah?{w}{clear}Here, can you read it out to me?{w}{clear}I can't see.

speak;Farmhand;Okay -{w} let's see.{w}{clear}"To my father,{w} the honourable Duke of Setanta,{w} Boris Nelson Peter Patrick Ebbitt Gabriel Ewing O'Rourke Monroe,{w}{clear}And the people of this country to whom he is indebted to..."

speak;;"I am writing to you in a public letter in an attempt to appeal to your better judgement,{w} an appeal that at once must be prefaced with apology.{w} I realize now how rash a decision of mine it was to run off with the prince Marcel Milieu without your prior knowledge or consent.{w} I should have made a concerted effort to convince you,{w} both of his love,{w} and his desire,{w} to do right for both our countries.{w} I regret the loss of the opportunity immensely,{w} knowing that if I had had the patience,{w} we would not find ourselves in the position that we are in now...";center;;narration;;;;;8
# Transition - the governor's house at Wolfstock

speak;;You wish to stop Marcel's passage because you view him as a criminal,{w} but as far as I can see,{w} the only crime he has committed is the mere act of loving me,{w} and it is for this that you wish to punish him,{w} and punish me,{w} for doing what comes naturally to ourselves.{w} This vindictive and immature abuse of power -{w} for what else would you call this persecution which has no logical or rational justification? -{w} must cease immediately,{w} both for the good of the country,{w} and for our own personal well-being.{w} If you were to take away Marcel,{w} I would be left with nothing left to live for.{w} I would throw away my life if I were separated from him.{w} If you think that you can take him away from me,{w} and bring me back to live with you,{w} you are living in a past era with a spent future...;center;;narration;;;;;8

speak;;The days where we could live together in peace have long since past.{w} You have to accept the fact that I have grown, Father.{w} I am old enough to make my own decisions,{w} and I am strong enough to bear their consequences.{w} I am aware that if I cross the border,{w} I will never see you again...;center;;narration;;;;;8

speak;;"...and the thought of it brings me to tears,{w} to think that I will never see you again,{w} that we will never speak again.{w} That you will never again consider us father and daughter.{w} And that it can't be avoided,{w} and can never be changed.{w} Regardless,{w} it is a decision that I must make,{w} it is something that I must do.{w} I know that I must leave behind my life here,{w} my country of birth,{w} in order to continue living,{w} even though it leaves inside a part of me to die.{w} I know that the grief of leaving you behind may kill me,{w} I know that I may forever regret the decision I've made for the rest of my life -{w} I may -{w} I may -{w} but I know,{w} I know that regardless of how happily I may live here,{w} that life would be tainted by the life I've yet to live.{w} I beg of you, Father,{w} do not deny me the potential to be happy.{w} Allow us to cross the border.{w} I will always be your loving daughter.{w}{clear}Madeline Milieu.;center;;narration;;;;;8
speak;Boris;If we kill Marcel,{w} we as good as kill my daughter.{w}{clear}But we can't let them escape.

speak;Boris;Madeline is too young to understand the transience of such feelings.{w}{clear}People are adept at such trickery,{w} especially in regards to themselves.{w}{clear}They convince themselves they love someone without ever even knowing who they are,{w} invent all sorts of reasons,{w} scribble imaginary lines in the sky,{w} and say that their love is written in the stars,{w} but there is a high difference between conviction,{w} and knowledge.{w}{clear}Madeline, in this letter,{w} displays conviction,{w} but it is clear,{w} in regards to Marcel,{w} in regards to love -{w} she doesn't know a thing.{w}{clear}It would be a fatal mistake to let her go.{w}{clear}But we can't kill him.
speak;Fintan;But if we capture him,{w} will there not be a risk of war with Crucible?
speak;Boris;No matter how formidable their military,{w} Crucible would not want to fight a war on two fronts.{w}{clear}As long as we leave them the option of negotiation,{w} they won't declare war.
speak;Boris;That's a different matter entirely.{w}{clear}Aggression from him can smoothed over later,{w} but it won't be tolerated coming from me.{w}{clear}Besides, that's the least of his mistakes.
speak;Fintan;Do you think there's any truth to the story they've told us?
speak;Boris;Of course he got captured.{w}{clear}If he didn't,{w} they'd use him as a means for free passage,{w} and not have to resort to this desperate attempt.
speak;Fintan;Won't her mental state be significantly altered by the departure of Marcel?

speak;Boris;As long as he's kept alive,{w} then regardless of how long she is parted,{w}{clear}A part of her heart will nuture the believe that they'll one day be together,{w} which will keep her going until she meets a new man,{w} and then,{w} whether she likes it or not,{w} she'll be swept off her feet,{w}{clear}And Marcel will merely be a fleeting adolescent memory.{w}{clear}A comforting piece of nostalgia perhaps.{w}{clear}Nothing more.
speak;Boris;Tell Chelsea to deliver this message.{w}{clear}In the meantime, ready the troops.{w}{clear}When they return with a rejection letter,{w} take it as permission to attack.
speak;Boris;The army is yours to command.{w}{clear}I put my complete faith in your abilities.
speak;Anthony;Somewhere near the stables -{w} look,{w} thank you for your help.
speak;Cecelia;Nah, don't mention it -{w} how'd you write so many?
speak;Anthony;Madeline wrote the original,{w} and one of our magicians, Claude,{w} duplicated it.
speak;Anthony;Do child labour laws apply on a battlefield?
speak;Anthony;Um.{w}{clear}Alice, could you do me a favour and fetch Marcel?{w}{clear}I don't want to miss the messenger.
speak;Alice;No, you don't understand.{w}{clear}I think I'm supposed to bring you with me.
speak;Marcel;I've still got some things to sort out,{w} so you might have to wait a while.
speak;Alice;Do you not get nervous before a battle?
speak;Marcel;I used to.{w}{clear}I still do.{w}{clear}But not in the same way.;;130;;;;;;1
speak;Alice;Marcel.{w}{clear}If you had a choice between living later,{w} or dying soon,{w} what would you choose?
speak;Alice;Would you sacrifice your life to save someone,{w} or would you save yourself?
speak;Alice;It is not right to believe you're fault.
speak;Alice;You are not at fault for your mother's death.
speak;Alice;Then why do you believe in what you believe?
speak;Marcel;What I believe is what I believe in.{w}{clear}I don't have to say it to you or myself.{w}{clear}Alice, you don't need to know.
speak;Alice;Do you even believe in anything?
speak;Marcel;Of course I do, but you don't need to know.
speak;Alice;Marcel, I want to help you.
speak;Marcel;How can you help me?{w}{clear}What can you do?{w}{clear}Can you raise the dead?{w}{clear}Can you turn back time?;;140;;;;;;1

speak;Marcel;So what does it do, Alice?{w}{clear}What does it do?{w}{clear}I tell you,{w} you say it's all better,{w} but what does it do?{w}{clear}It's still there,{w} by my side,{w} looming over every day,{w}{clear}Every day I think about her.{w}{clear}Every single day, Alice.{w}{clear}Not a moment in time,{w} not a waking minute,{w} that I don't hate the fact she's gone.{w}{clear}Maybe with time,{w} I can gain enough distance,{w} but until that day comes,{w} when it comes,{w} if it comes...{w}{clear}There is nothing you can do to help me.
speak;Anthony;The letters have been delivered.{w}{clear}Where were you?
speak;Marcel;Just going over the plan again.{w}{clear}With Hamsen.
speak;Anthony;Generous to call it a plan.
speak;Marcel;Striking before the enemy can strike back is a plan of sorts.
speak;Anthony;In order to kill a man,{w} you must kill him.
speak;Marcel;Anyway, once a battle starts,{w} all strategy goes out the window.
speak;Anthony;Seems to be our way of doing it.
speak;Marcel;Hey, Madeline,{w} the letter's been delivered.
speak;Madeline;I don't think it's going to make much of a difference.
speak;Madeline;Not a case of...{w}{clear}Regardless, you're not the one to convince.
speak;Chelsea;Message for Anthony and Marcel Milieu,{w} on behalf of his Excellency,{w} the head of state,{w} Duke Boris Nelson Peter Patrick Ebbitt Gabriel Ewing O'Rourke Monroe.
speak;Marcel;I suppose we should get ready then.
# Marcel and Anthony and Madeline walk around the tents.
speak;Marcel;James, Claude, Claudia,{w} we're all ready to go,{w} come on!
speak;James;Want me to perform your last rites before we leave?
speak;Marcel;Sure you want to fight, Claude?
speak;Claude;What else am I supposed to do?
speak;Claudia;Don't worry.{w}{clear}If this idiot James can survive on a battlefield,{w} anyone can.
speak;James;Marcel,{w} why are these kids so mean to me?
speak;Madeline;Cindy, Simone, Cecelia!{w}{clear}Get your gear ready!;;125;;;;;;1
speak;Simone;Yeah, in a minute,{w} just give me sec...
speak;Cecelia;Typical Simone.{w}{clear}Always leaving everything to the last minute.
speak;Marcel;Thank you............... {w}I see.|Tell him I said 'no',{w} but make it sound as if you're putting it politely,{w} and that I actually said something far worse.
# Chelsea returns the message. Soon, a stream of troops pours out from the border castle.
